NBA Top 100 Players 2021-2022 | Ranking The Best Basketball Players & Prop BetsPosted: Oct 31, 2021Last updated: Feb 8, 2022The NBA‚Äôs 75th season is just around the corner, as the 2021-22 campaign is set to begin Tuesday, October 19. Starting off the action is a matchup between last year‚Äôs Eastern Conference heavyweights ‚Äî the Brooklyn Nets and Milwaukee Bucks ‚Äî followed by a meeting between the Golden State Warriors and new-look Los Angeles Lakers.In preparation for the upcoming year, we at The Game Day took the liberty of ranking the top 100 players in the NBA. This was no easy list to compile given the vast amount of talent across the league, and do note that it is entirely subjective.Additionally, if you‚Äôre looking to place a few preseason player and team prop bets before the games are underway, you‚Äôve come to the right place. Below, you‚Äôll find some of our favorite picks mixed into the NBA Top 100 list, including a few major NBA award winners.With that said, let‚Äôs dive right in.Looking to bet on the NBA this season? Do you think you have an edge on your favorite player? Caesars is one of our favorite sportsbooks for NBA betting. Take advantage of Caesars Sportsbook‚Äôs outstanding welcome bonus, which matches your first deposit up to $1,500 when you use our promo code GAMEDAYCZR.Read Chris Wassel‚Äôs Caesars Sportsbook review¬†for more insight and get your welcome bonus below, or continue reading our NBA Top 100.Intuitive AppPlenty of Markets & Bet TypesVIP Rewards SystemFirst Bet InsuranceNew Customers Only, 21+. T&C‚Äôs Apply.Bank TransferIn what was arguably one of the most underrated acquisitions of the offseason, the New York Knicks signed four-time All-Star Kemba Walker to a two-year contract. Although the high-scoring point guard isn‚Äôt the player he once was with the Charlotte Hornets, New York clearly upgraded at the position by bringing him in.A native of the Bronx, Walker will be welcomed with open arms by Knicks fans hoping to see their team make consecutive playoff appearances for the first time since 2013.If Walker proves to be a solid fit in Tom Thibodeau‚Äòs system alongside Julius Randle and RJ Barrett, New York should have no issue returning to the postseason despite playing in a surprisingly crowded Eastern Conference.prop bet Bet $20, Payout $33Kemba Walker could experience a renaissance year with his hometown New York Knicks in 2021-22. (Image: USA TODAY Sports)Toronto Raptors forward OG Anunoby is one of the most popular picks to win Most Improved Player in 2021-22, and it‚Äôs not hard to see why. The 24-year-old has made large strides in each of his first four NBA seasons, but he feels especially primed to have a breakout year.With Kyle Lowry out of the picture, someone on this Raptors team needs to step up and become the go-to guy. Pascal Siakam floundered when given the opportunity last year, and Fred VanVleet isn‚Äôt a No. 1 option.That leaves the up-and-coming Anunoby, a rock-solid two-way wing with an improved shooting touch and hunger for the spotlight. If he can lead the Raptors back to the playoffs in 2022 after a disappointing year in Tampa Bay, his name will be rightfully be at the forefront of the conversation.Player Prop Bet $20, Payout $420A breakout season could be on the horizon for Toronto Raptors wing OG Anunoby. (Image: USA TODAY Sports)The Chicago Bulls are going to be a ton of fun this season. Zach LaVine‚Äòs monstrous season wasn‚Äôt enough to carry them into the postseason in 2020-21, but with the help the franchise got him this offseason, Chicago may be a virtual shoo-in this year.In addition to acquiring Nikola Vuƒçeviƒá at the trade deadline, the Bulls also added DeMar DeRozan and Lonzo Ball via free agency, building one of the more talented starting rotations in the NBA in the process.With that said, it should be known that this is still LaVine‚Äôs team. The high-flying guard averaged 27.4 points per game on near-50/40/90 splits in 2020-21, and the additions of DeRozan and Ball should lead to more open looks.Expect LaVine to lead the Bulls to their first postseason appearance since 2017 ‚Äî and look for them to rack up plenty of wins along the way.over-under Bet $20, Payout $38The Chicago Bulls look like one of the most talented teams in the Eastern Conference on paper, but will it translate to success on the court? (Image: USA TODAY Sports)Kevin Durant put together one of the best seasons of his career in 2020-21, and that‚Äôs saying a lot considering the 33-year-old is a former MVP, 11x All-Star, and 4x Scoring Champion.¬†Durant was as efficient as ever in his debut year with the Brooklyn Nets, pouring in 26.9 points per game and shooting a career-high 45% from three-point range.However, where the Slim Reaper really brought his A-game was in the playoffs, where he averaged an absurd 34.3 points, 9.3 rebounds, and 4.4 assists per game. He was at his best in Brooklyn‚Äôs Game 5 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks, putting together a 49-point triple-double in one of the single-greatest playoff performances in NBA history.To put it simply, there‚Äôs no stopping KD. As long as he can stay healthy this year and keep his production up, there won‚Äôt be anybody standing in the way of him earning his second Most Valuable Player award.Player Prop Bet $20, Payout $160

Skyler Carlin2 days agoRead moreBet NowBet NowThu 03/31, 7:00 PM ET +4.5-110-4.5-110Sat 04/02, 6:09 PM ET +4-110-4.5-110Sat 04/02, 8:49 PM ET Terms & conditions applyTerms & conditions applyTerms & conditions applyTerms & conditions applyTerms & conditions applyTerms & conditions applyTerms & conditions applyTerms & conditions applyTerms & conditions applyThe Villanova Wildcats have won four of their last five meetings with the Kansas Jayhawks dating back to 2013, with two of those wins coming in the NCAA Tournament (2016 Elite Eight, 2018 Final Four). Betting Impact:Despite Villanova's dominance in this series, the Jayhawks are -4.5 point favorites, per BettingPros consensus odds. This point spread is slightly up from an initial opening of -4, and the movement may be due to the verification that Wildcats second-leading scorer, Justin Moore, will miss the game after suffering a torn Achilles against Houston. Villanova has covered the spread in all four NCAA Tournament games thus far, and are 21-6 ATS in its last 27 tournament games overall. Kansas is 6-2 ATS in its last eight games, but has covered just two of its last seven NCAA Tournament games. The underdog has covered the spread in four of the last five meetings between these teams. The Duke Blue Devils have been bet up from -4 to -4.5 point favorites for their Sweet 16 matchup against the North Carolina Tar Heels, per BettingPros consensus odds.
Betting Impact:North Carolina is making its 21st Final Four appearance, the most all-time. While North Carolina extends its record for most Final Four appearances, Duke head coach Mike Krzyzewski makes a record 13th Final Four appearance, passing John Wooden for the most all-time. Krzyzewski is also the tenth head coach to make a Final Four in his last season. The Blue Devils went 1-1 SU and ATS in two regular-season meetings against the Tar Heels. North Carolina has covered the spread in all four NCAA Tournament games, and Duke has covered its last three, which followed a span of seven consecutive NCAA Tournament games where it did not cover the spread. The over/under has much more volatility than the point spread, as some sportsbooks are as low as 150.5 points and as high as 151.5. The two regular-season meetings between Duke and North Carolina totaled 154 and 175 points, each cashing the over. The over is 5-2 in North Carolina‚Äôs last seven games as underdogs and 8-2 in Duke‚Äôs previous ten. The Duke-North Carolina game is likely to have the biggest handle of any college basketball game this season, and sportsbooks are likely expecting the majority of the betting public to back the Blue Devils. 
Leading up to Saturday's Final Four, the Duke Blue Devils have the best odds of all four teams to win the national championship. Betting Impact:Per DraftKings, each team's odds to win the national championship are as follows: Duke (+155), Kansas (+185), Villanova (+450), North Carolina (+500). The Blue Devils and Jayhawks have -195 and -180 ML odds, respectively, to win their Final Four matchups. If they do, it would set up a nostalgic rematch in Mike Krzyzewski's last game, as he beat Kansas in 1991 for his first-ever national championship. The Kansas Jayhawks have opened as -6 point favorites for their Elite Eight matchup against the Miami Hurricanes, with an O/U of 147.5 points, per BettingPros consensus odds. Betting Impact:The Miami Hurricanes earned their first-ever Elite Eight appearance with a dominating 14-point victory over Iowa State. Combined with Saint Peter‚Äôs deep run, their win makes it ten of the past 11 NCAA Tournaments where at least one No. 7 seed or lower has reached the Elite Eight. Kansas‚Äô Sweet 16 victory over Providence was also historic, as it was the Jayhawks‚Äô 2,354th win, breaking a tie with Kentucky for the most wins in Division I. This is now Bill Self‚Äôs 11th career Elite Eight appearance and ninth as Jayhawks head coach. As the lone remaining No. 1 seed, Kansas kept the streak alive that at least one No. 1 seed has made the Elite Eight in every NCAA Tournament since seeding began in 1979. However, this is the first time fewer than two No. 1 seeds have made the Regional Finals since 2013. Kansas has been favored in all but one of its 38 games this season. The Jayhawks have failed to cover their last two games, which followed a streak of five consecutive covers. Miami has covered four straight games and six of its previous seven.

The Saint Peter's Peacocks are the first-ever No. 15 seed to advance to the Elite Eight, and will look to continue making history as underdogs against the North Carolina Tar Heels. Betting Impact:The Tar Heels are -8 point favorites with an O/U of 137 points, per BettingPros consensus odds. Before this year's Peacocks team, the lowest seed ever to make an Elite Eight was a No. 12 seed (2002 Missouri, 2021 Oregon State). Conversely, the North Carolina Tar Heels are making their 27th Elite Eight appearance and first since 2017. North Carolina advanced to the Elite Eight with a 73-66 win over UCLA. The victory was UNC's 17th straight over Pac-12 teams. While not as improbable as Saint Peter's run, North Carolina had to win two of three tournament games as underdogs to be in this position. The Tar Heels improved to 10-4 SU all-time as a No. 8 seed and reached the Final Four as a No. 8 seed in 2000. Hubert Davis is now the fifth head coach to make an Elite Eight appearance in his first season as a D-I head coach, and first since Stan Heath in 2002. Saint Peter's entered the NCAA Tournament as the best ATS team of any in the 68-team field, and now three straight wins and covers have improved its ATS record to 23-9. At most sportsbooks, Saint Peter's was 10,000:1 to win the national championship before the tournament. The Peacocks are the only team to win multiple games as a double-digit underdog in an NCAA Tournament since the tournament expanded in 1985. From 1985-2021, double-digit favorites in the Sweet 16 went 35-2 SU but went 0-2 this year after Saint Peter's win over Purdue and Arkansas' win over Gonzaga. Saint Peter's outright win over Purdue as +13 point underdogs was the biggest Sweet 16 upset since 1978.If you or someone you know has a gambling problem and wants help, please call 1-800-GAMBLER.All betting content on TheGameDay.com is exclusively intended for audience members 21 years and older who are permitted to gamble in legal states. Best DC Comics of 2019Comic Book HeraldA Comic Book Reading Order Guide For Beginners & FansJune 28, 2019 by Dave 1 Comment 2019 has been a challenging year for DC Comics, with operational changes leading to layoffs throughout the publishing arm, and high profile series like Heroes in Crisis suffering from extensively negative reviews. Many of the publisher‚Äôs most memorable 2019 events are exercises in crisis control, from Batman: Damned‚Äòs ‚ÄúBat-Penis‚Äù controversy (see also: sentences I‚Äôve always dreamed of writing) to the early removal of Tom King from Batman.Even with this, DC has published plenty of great stories, and continues to build an impressive network of top tier creative talent. Since acquiring Brian Michael Bendis from Marvel in 2018 (it wasn‚Äôt actually a sports style trade, but I prefer to phrase it that way), DC has also added the following list of heavy hitters:This is on top of pre-existing universe architects like King, Geoff Johns, and Scott Snyder (among many others!).The end result is a seemingly endless stream of ongoings and miniseries on my pull list of comics I collect week in and week out. We‚Äôre entering year 4 of the DC Rebirth era, and that‚Äôs an admittedly difficult spot to be ‚Äì the thrill of the ‚Äúnew‚Äù has worn off, and now DC faces a lot of questions about what they want their universe to look like for the long haul.These are the comics that are doing it best in 2019.Comic Book Herald is reader-supported. When you buy through links on our site, we may earn a qualifying affiliate commission.Comic Book Herald‚Äôs reading orders and guides are also made possible by reader support on Patreon, and generous reader donations.Any size contribution will help keep CBH alive and full of new comics guides and content. Support¬†CBH on Patreon¬†for exclusive rewards, or Donate here!¬†Thank you for reading!Become a Patron!This is a borderline best-of for me because in many ways Aquaman still feels more like a draft prospect than a fully fleshed out player ‚Äì even with complete arcs published, the creative vision of Deconnick and Robson Rocha feels like a lot of untapped potential.But oh that potential! There‚Äôs plenty of interesting world-building occurring in the early parts of Deconnick‚Äôs time writing an amnesiac Arthur Curry, and Rocha‚Äôs approach to storytelling makes for a visually compelling comic. I definitely think the best is yet to come on Aquaman, but even so, it remains one of the more interesting DC Comics of the year.If you‚Äôre surprised to find Hawkman among DC‚Äôs best of 2019, well, so was I. Nonetheless, Robert Vendetti and Bryan Hitch have been hard at work on (arguably) DC‚Äôs most underrated title, spinning the return of Carter Hall (via DC Metal) into an extremely fresh take on the complicated character.After an inconsistent run on Justice League to kick off DC Rebirth, Hitch is back to conveying incredibly cinematic visuals on the page, as he and Vendetti lean into Hawkman‚Äôs roots as an archaeologist. I don‚Äôt exaggerate when saying this is the most I‚Äôve ever¬†liked Carter Hall.It hasn‚Äôt received even a fraction of the hype, but Female Furies is a worthy companion piece to Tom King and Mitch Gerad‚Äôs Mister Miracle. Making Granny Goodness a sympathetic figure, and a clear target of an inherent patriarchy at the center of Apokolips is no easy chore, and Female Furies not only succeeds, but entertains while doing so.Through the six issue miniseries, Cecil Castelluci and Adriana Melo dig into the harsh realities of the Furies fighting force, and the characters of Big Barda, Aurelie, Mad Harriet, Lashina, Bernadeth and Stompa. It‚Äôs an untapped corner of Apokoliptin myth, with a whip-smart layer of contemporary commentary.Following work on The Flintstones, Snagglepuss, and DC‚Äôs Nuclear Winter Special, writer Mark Russell is an ‚Äúauto pull‚Äù in my comics rotation. Russell‚Äôs brand of satire and humanism resonates deeply, and although I have absolutely zero nostalgic connection to The Wonder Twins, the prospect of Russell on such an odd piece of DC history was instantly tantalizing.Stephen Byrne‚Äôs art is perfectly suited for this high school setting, and¬†Wonder Twins¬†manages to wrangle¬†Super Friends¬†nostalgia into an extremely relevant story for 2019.Ever since Captain America 3: Civil War hit theaters, I‚Äôve said it‚Äôs a fool‚Äôs errand to question the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Pulling off a movie of that scale, with that many moving pieces proved to me once and for all that the creative players involved were a near lock on a quality offering (and that was before we saw the true scale in Infinity War).That‚Äôs also how I‚Äôve come to feel about comics written by Tom Taylor. No matter how outlandish the premise (a videogame were Superman goes Tyrant-mode or a Wolverine series featuring a *gasps* real live girl!) Taylor delivers some of the best superhero comics available.DCeased pulls that trick off yet again, this time with a ‚ÄúMarvel Zombies‚Äù style exploration of the DC Universe. While I still wish this was an in continuity event (let Taylor get wild, you cowards!), the freedom to explore free from continuity opens a lot of storytelling doors.The thing about this comic is that Matt Fraction (Sex Criminals, Hawkeye) and Steve Lieber (Superior Foes of Spider-Man) are responsible, and every indication is that it *should*¬† be one for the ages. Even with a limited sample available, I can say I unequivocally love ‚ÄúSuperman‚Äôs Pal, Jimmy Olsen.‚Äù It‚Äôs hilarious, and inventive, and explores way more of the DC Universe than I expected.Above all else,¬†Jimmy Olsen¬†is challenging, zigzagging between eras and plotlines with reckless abandon, leaving only your faith in a guiding hand to keep the story from unraveling. Fraction and Lieber seem intent on ensuring all twelve issues of the series are in your hands before any accurate assessment can be levied, which certainly has both pros and cons. As a result, I‚Äôve softened mildly on my assumptions that this would be my favorite DC Comic of 2019, and now find it merely quite good, with the possibility that I‚Äôll have a spot for the completed work here again in 2020!A Green Lantern comic by the creative team of Grant Morrison and Liam Sharp is one of those sure bets that I could feel comfortable including on a best-of list sight unseen.I‚Äôm pulling and reading issue every issue the moment they‚Äôre released, but I‚Äôm just saying, my confidence in Morrison and Sharp is¬†that¬†high.Since Morrison has a history with the DC Universe dating back to the late 80‚Äôs, The Green Lantern is also held to the standard of his past work, which increases the complexity of evaluation. Ultimately I know this take on Hal Jordan, space cop is compared to some of the greatest runs in DC history. The looming shadow of reports that this is Morrison‚Äôs¬†final¬†superhero comic (we‚Äôll see) also offer some legacy gravitas to a series that stands out regardless.I‚Äôve written extensively in a ‚ÄúPreviously On‚Äù column why I love ‚ÄúThe Wild Storm‚Äù by Warren Ellis and Jon Davis-Hunt. I‚Äôll add here that 2019 has been especially exciting as it houses the conclusion of this 24 issue narrative, and that the slow-burn is paying off in tremendous ways. Ellis and Davis-Hunt have effectively ramped up to ‚ÄúThe Authority‚Äù portion of the proceedings, which means reimagined Jenny Sparks, Midnighter and Apollo (among others).It‚Äôs a contemporary masterclass in updating a shared universe and Jon Davis-Hunt is doing some of the best work in superhero comics. Plus, you can read all 24 issues right now, and have a full sense of story completion!Gene Luen Yang is one of the surest creative bets in comics, and his all ages work with artist Gurihiru is an instant classic, both an homage to Superman‚Äôs deep history and much-needed socio-political reflection of the Superman myth‚Äôs place in 2019.The oversized three issue book has quickly become one of my most eagerly anticipated releases, and even with the final third yet to be released in 2020, there‚Äôs no doubt that¬†Superman Smashes The Klan¬†is a remarkable testament to how effective true all ages works from the Big 2 can be in the right creative hands.The world of Batman is an unsurprisingly crowded realm this year, with all sorts of creative powerhouses taking their turn at the caped crusader. In Batman, Tom King is unveiling his years in the making love-story, in ‚ÄúDetective Comics‚Äù writer Peter Tomasi is taking the iconic title in a new direction, in ‚ÄúBatman Who Laughs‚Äù Scott Snyder and Jock reunite for a Dark Nights Metal spinoff, and in ‚ÄúBatman Universe‚Äù Brian Michael Bendis and Nick Derington are giving the Walmart faithful gorgeous Bat-adventures.And that‚Äôs before we get to ‚ÄúBlack Label,‚Äù which is apparently going to be nothing but a Batman U showcase!Above all, though, I‚Äôm most excited for Batman: Last Knight on Earth which reunites New 52 Batman and Dark Nights Metal creative combo Scott Snyder and Greg Capullo. Snyder and Capullo have described the oversized three issue collection as their Dark Knight Returns, and they‚Äôre not overselling the goods. ‚ÄúLast Knight on Earth‚Äù is a post-apocalyptic /¬†Mad Max¬†style narrative in which Bruce Wayne awakens in a surreal DC Universe gone wrong and sets to make things right.Rather than lean in to the grim situation, Snyder and Capullo have¬†fun¬†with the premise, giving Batman a Joker-head to carry around on his newfound, perhaps final quest. It‚Äôs a gorgeous looking comic with all the absolute comic book conceptual joy of Metal.If you only read one comic book series in the DC Universe in 2019, make it Batman: Last Knight on Earth!Filed Under: Featured Tagged With: best of 2019, DC ComicsIf you like Comic Book Herald, and are able to donate, any small contribution will help keep CBH alive and full of new comics guides and content. Donate here! Or, support CBH on Patreon for exclusive rewards! Thank you for reading!Dave is the founder and Editor-in-Chief of Comic Book Herald, and also the Boss of assigning himself fancy titles. He's a long-time comic book fan, and can be seen most evenings in Batman pajama pants. Contact Dave @comicbookherald on Twitter or via email at dave@comicbookherald.com.
Chris J says September 14, 2019 at 9:59 pmWell, overall I can‚Äôt fault your choices as they are ‚Äòyour preferences‚Äô. However, I have to say that DC has long since disenfranchised me from their fold, something I‚Äôve been somewhat loathe to admit having been a fan of their characters since the 50s and 60s. And, having been a fan, a comics artist and storyteller, back issue dealer, comic book store manager, and even having worked as a sales manager for a small comics publisher in the past (Viz), my perspective is rooted in a breadth of perspectives and experience. It‚Äôs not better than yours, but also lends itself more, perhaps of a longer perspective.While I might still be attracted to some DC characters and ever so hopeful, there have been so many missteps in the past ten years (and this also by accounts includes Marvel as well) that I no longer really‚Ä¶care about the characters. I bear that excuse and decision. Do I blame DC? No, I guess they‚Äôre doing the best they can in an exceedingly difficult publishing environment, and I have little doubt that the corporate folks who engineered the move to LA and are no doubt more bottom-line concerned has put the fear of god (getting fired, not achieving better sales, etc.) into the existing administrative/editorial pool that the general consensus of publishing is now based as much on focus groups, appealing to the middle ground, and‚Ä¶let‚Äôs face it‚Ä¶playing to the masses rather than‚Ä¶whatever they SHOULD be doing. Obviously, they haven‚Äôt figured it out, they‚Äôre inan environment where the staff don‚Äôt know what to do, and whatever they choose, might bring them all to the exit door. I dunno. I wish them all luck, but I barely recognize any of these characters. Retcons run rampant, rebirths, re-issues, re-starts with #1, crisis this and crisis that, crossovers that literally strip the money out of feeble-minded fans who are addicted and afraid to  miss out‚Ä¶what a mess. 50 BEST PLAYERS IN THE NBA

There are roughly a million ways to rank and order players in today‚Äôs analytically inclined NBA where stats and information can overwhelm those of us who don‚Äôt have a degree in quantum physics. Seriously, pick just about any stat or specific skill‚Äîlike offensive rating, win shares, +/-, or shooting percentage on corner threes‚Äîand we can neatly order the 500-plus players who will be on an NBA roster this season into a coherent hierarchy.But when wading into a topic as arbitrary, and often inflammatory, as who are the NBA‚Äôs 50 best players, you often reach a state of chaos before ever approaching any sort of consensus. Which, honestly, is the way it should be when the rankings rely largely on the eye test mixed in with a few other factors.While it‚Äôs kind of an absurd proposition, of course, to accurately and definitively order basketball‚Äôs best players, it‚Äôs what we love to do. And we have the chutzpah to tell you that we do it better than anybody else out there. So we‚Äôre back, before the start of what we hope is a truly normal basketball season after two straight weird ones, to offer up our annual NBA player rankings.Exhaustively argued and astutely ordered, our readers know ranking the top 50 players in the NBA is a tradition here at Complex Sports. But before wading into this year‚Äôs version, you should know that we‚Äôve anointed someone new as basketball‚Äôs best. Spoiler alert: the reign of LeBron James as the NBA‚Äôs unquestioned No. 1 baller has ended. While LeBron stans and Lakers fans may protest, we expect the majority of readers will not have any issues with our new No. 1. Nor will they have any issues with our top 5. Or probably the top 10. The controversies and complaints start once we get into the teens and we‚Äôre prepared to never hear the end of it for placing the forever polarizing Draymond Green on our list yet again.We think you‚Äôll agree with how the majority of our rankings shook out, knowing, of course, that this exercise will forever be rooted in imperfect science. You‚Äôll probably raise a few eyebrows or possibly even curse our name as you scroll through. We get it. We respect it. Just read the reasons why we moved Khris Middleton way up and left a few familiar names from previous seasons off before roasting us on Twitter, please.

The 30 Best DC Comics of All-Time, RankedThough I was chomping at the bit to do a ‚ÄúTop 30 Marvel Comics‚Äù it turns out there was a great list to that effect in October. But there was no such list for the ‚ÄúDistinguished Competition‚Äù on the site, so here we go: these are my top 30 favorite DC comics.As a note, these will include both regular DC superhero comics like Wonder Woman and Green Lantern, as well as several entries from their storied Vertigo imprint. When it gets down to the top ten, don‚Äôt be surprised to see significant overlap with our recent ‚Äú50 Best Graphic Novels of All Time‚Äù list.Starting out with one of those imprints, DMZ both feels timeless in its depiction of a divided America and like a narrative and artistic time capsule from the Post-9/11 era of dystopian comics. The story follows a journalist trapped in Manhattan, now the eponymous DMZ between American factions, where the war-torn stories dominating the early 2000s news cycles take on a distinctly American flavor.It would be reductive but not inaccurate to call Longbow Hunters the Dark Knight Returns or Batman: Year One for Green Arrow. It‚Äôs a grittier depiction of the character, but with a painterly style that helps distinguish it from others in that genre. It‚Äôs stylish and is a solid introduction to those looking to get more into the psyche of Oliver Queen.George Perez‚Äôs defining run on Wonder Woman helped cement many of the qualities that are readily identified with the hero today. Gods and Mortals thrusts Wonder Woman into the midst of the drama of the gods and puts her role as a Daughter of Themyscira at the forefront of her journey into the modern world.¬†New Frontier is Darwyn Cooke‚Äôs love letter to the Gold and Silver ages of comics, telling a story that interweaves the fictional evolution of the characters post WW2 with the real-world crises from McCarthyism to Jim Crow. It manages to both tell a story about a civil conflict within superheroes between the state-sanctioned ones and vigilantes working in the shadows while managing to never get too bogged down in grittiness and showcasing the best of these characters.Tom King‚Äôs run on Batman is good, don‚Äôt get me wrong, but it‚Äôs his Mister Miracle that‚Äôs special. In a lot of ways, Mister Miracle feels like a follow-up to his equally personal and similarly color-scheme‚Äôd vision series. Here, New Gods hero Mister Miracle is struggling with his past traumas and his domestic life with his wife and fellow New Gods refugee Big Barda. Like with Vision, Tom King knows how to effectively funnel cosmic sci-fi into a personal family narrative.Scott Snyder is a master of gothic horror, and the Court of Owls villain introduced at the start of his New 52 run may be one of the more iconic entries to Batman‚Äôs rogue‚Äôs gallery in recent years. Here, a shadowy cabal of masked elites threatens one area Bruce always felt was his strength: his knowledge and understanding of Gotham City. How the mystery unfolds leaves a little to be desired, but all-in-all it‚Äôs a compelling Bruce Wayne story that introduces an instant-classic villain.Aquaman‚Äôs reputation as a joke hero has always been somewhat undeserved, and nowhere is that status better struck down than in Geoff Johns‚Äô New 52 reboot. Here, Aquaman‚Äôs adventures open up an undersea world of court intrigue worthy of Game of Thrones and elements of Lovecraftian horror in the depths of the sea. It‚Äôs an exciting, compelling homecoming for the rebooted Arthur Curry.This series doesn‚Äôt introduce John Constantine, that honor goes to a book later on this list, but it‚Äôs one of the stories that best illustrate the character by dragging him through some of his lowest moments. Here, the chain-smoking British exorcist faces his own mortality as he‚Äôs‚Äîunderstandably given the number of cigarettes he inhales‚Äîdiagnosed with lung cancer. In this Garth Ennis story, Constantine‚Äôs life opens up more and readers get to know the man more even as his end seems nigh. It also shows Constantine at his best: dancing around and double-dealing cosmic forces and forever staying just barely one step ahead.In one of the best single-issue stories, a villain traps Superman in an artificial construct by giving him what he‚Äôs always dreamed of: a chance to experience life on his homeworld. It‚Äôs an interesting conceit that feels like a precursor to the later Elseworlds brand, and culminates with Superman having to give a heartbreaking farewell to a vision of everything he wanted. In just one issue, Alan Moore gets at the heart of the character in a way that few others accomplish.While Year One‚Äôs portrayal of Batman and Jim Gordon‚Äôs relationship is rightly praised, one of the best aspects of the comic is the repositioning of Batman as ‚Äúthe guy who beats up street-level crooks‚Äù -- though don‚Äôt get me wrong, there‚Äôs plenty of that -- to a vigilante willing to take on the wealthy and powerful that others won‚Äôt touch. It‚Äôs one thing when those are cartoonish businessmen like The Penguin, but Batman: Year One sends its hero after police commissioners and mayors, and gives new nuance to the character‚Äôs frequent clashes with authority figures throughout his mythos.The Sinestro Corps War is epic. It marks one of the best occasions where the writers get to let loose and fully embrace the space opera side of the character. Green Lantern Hal Jordan goes toe-to-toe with former comrade turned nemesis Sinestro in an epic battle across the stars. The central conflict is great, but the splintering of the emotional spectrum into multiple Lantern corps was one of the best changes to the character‚Äôs mythology in years and helped give the event a lasting weight.The ‚Äútwist‚Äù in Under the Hood is set up in the Hush storyline, but it‚Äôs how the mystery unfolds in Under the Hood that‚Äôs got the real staying power. A specter of Batman‚Äôs past comes back to haunt him and is picking off Gotham‚Äôs villains one by one. Like with Court of Owls, Under the Hood also introduces a villain into Batman‚Äôs rogues' gallery that became an instant classic. There‚Äôs a fair amount made in Batman media about his non-fatal code, but it‚Äôs a conflict explored at its best here.This Superman spin on the nature vs nurture debate looks at how the Man of Steel might have been a different hero with just a slight change in the trajectory of the Krypton escape vessel. Here, Superman grows up in Stalin‚Äôs Soviet Union, a fact that changes not just his life but ripples out into other heroes and villains across the DC universe. The 1950s Elseworlds versions of the various characters are all fun and interesting, but it‚Äôs the character study of Superman‚Äôs values that helps make the book so memorable.There‚Äôs a lot of good Teen Titans stories, but The Judas Contract is the best and most memorable of Marv Wolfman and George P√©rez‚Äôs storied run. The Teen Titans are a close-knit team that‚Äôs torn apart when a new member is revealed to be a traitor. It was a popular book, but The Judas Contract really put the Teen Titans on the map.It‚Äôs not uncommon for characters to get rebooted or reset in one way or another, especially at D.C., but it‚Äôs a rare pleasure to watch that happen on the page. In Dennis O'Neil‚Äôs run on the question, his own struggles with addiction play out in the noir-infused character. The eponymous hero is beaten nearly to death at the end of the first issue, and much of the rest of the first volume is the character slowly building himself back up from the ground but also questioning what it means to be an investigative hero and some hard questions about the use of violence to that end.Note: sadly the only accessible version of this, at the time of writing, is as single issues on ComixologyPut the ill-fated recent TV show out of your mind, Y: The Last Man is an incredible (and complete) journey following the last man alive on the planet as the world struggles with all the Y-chromosome folks suddenly dropping dead. It‚Äôs an interesting premise with a very new order to the world, and as he‚Äôd later do with Saga, writer Brian K. Vaughan excels in exploring through that space with a small and very believable cast of characters.Fables, the story of the interwoven lives of various fairy tale denizens living in a magical borough of New York, loses some steam as it goes on. But if it‚Äôs a story with some lows, it‚Äôs certainly worth reading for its highs. When writer Bill Willingham leans in on the noir or fantasy epic sides of the story, particularly with sections following grizzled sheriff Bigby Wolf, it‚Äôs a thrilling ride.The New 52 relaunch had some misses for DC, but where it hit (like Court of Owls and Aquaman) it did so in a big way, and one of those who benefitted the most was Amazonian Diana Prince. Updating and truly living up to the mythological groundwork laid in Gods and Mortals, the New 52 reboot for Wonder Woman adds new wrinkles into her origin and modernizes the Greek pantheon into a compelling urban fantasy series that‚Äôs an easy recommendation for any fans of mythology, comics or otherwise.One of the most fun aspects of American Vampire is how willing writer Scott Snyder is to throw out the traditional vampire lore. With various ‚Äústrains‚Äù of vampirism, Snyder throws out the old rules about sunlight and silver in favor of new, wholly American takes on the myth. It‚Äôs a decade-hopping tale that starts with a young woman in the Golden Age of Hollywood abused and left for dead, but the story expands over time into a story of grudges and obsessions that span human lifetimes.Jeph Loeb and Tim Sale‚Äôs The Long Halloween is widely beloved, but spoiler alert: you won‚Äôt find it on this list. For my money, the pair‚Äôs best work at DC Comics was Superman for All Seasons. It‚Äôs fairly simple as far as Superman stories go, but its strength is in tapping into the minds of the supporting cast closest to Clark Kent. Each of the stories offers a beautiful and well-written perspective on the hero with a masterful, Norman Rockwell-esque visual style that‚Äôs Tim Sale at his best. There‚Äôs rarely been a more heartfelt encapsulation of the Man of Steel, though there‚Äôs at least one better Superman story later on in this list.This won‚Äôt be Alan Moore‚Äôs last entry in the Top 10, and anyone who has read a ‚ÄúBest of DC‚Äù list will understand why. But before‚Ä¶ that elephant in the room, Alan Moore breathed new life into the superhero horror character Swamp Thing. The whole run is great, but the first volume‚Äôs Ship of Theseus reinvention of the character is a bold and defining turn.The recent love of embracing the silliness of Silver Age villains and humorous juxtaposition against over-the-top violence in media like the Harley Quinn show can, in some ways, be traced back to Gail Simone‚Äôs seminal Secret Six. It‚Äôs the story of a team of villains with some high body counts, but it‚Äôs impossible not to fall in love with the new takes on villains like Bane and Catman that help anchor this dysfunctional team.¬†In arguably the best Batman comic of the last 20 years, Bruce Wayne is nowhere to be found. At a time when Bruce is missing in action, former Robin Dick Grayson steps up to the mantle. But Snyder makes the keen observation that if the villains of Bruce Wayne‚Äôs Batman are a reflection of his psyche, then Grayson‚Äôs rogue‚Äôs gallery would look very different. Black Mirror, impeccably illustrated by artists Jock and Francesco Francavilla, pits Grayson against villains that play with Batman as legacy and generational privilege.To understand what makes Kingdom Come so great, it‚Äôs important to have some awareness of what comics were like in the 90s. The anti-hero was all the rage, with the traditional heroes on the wane. Kingdom Come takes that on directly, with a story that poses the question of whether or not there‚Äôs still a place in modern comics for characters like Superman or Batman. In doing so, it tells one of the best Elseworlds stories and arguably the greatest Justice League story.Neil Gaiman‚Äôs Sandman series is set in some ways inside the D.C. universe, but make no mistake: this is very much a Neil Gaiman story. Preludes and Nocturnes is the launch of Gaiman‚Äôs series, but Season of Mists is where Gaiman‚Äôs ethereal mythology story truly starts to shine. When Lucifer abdicates his responsibilities in overseeing Hell, a power struggle ensues as various gods try to seize the reins.Grant Morrison‚Äôs Superman is possibly the best depiction of the character as Clark Kent faces his own mortality. Morrison whole-heartedly embraces the full history of the character and paints a compelling portrait of what makes Superman an enduring figure. It‚Äôs hard to imagine a book that manages to deliver a fitting send-off to a character that‚Äôs been around since 1938, but Morrison manages it.In what may be Grant Morrison‚Äôs best work, and possibly the best non-Batman story out of D.C., Animal Man is a mind-bending take on the then-neglected Silver Age hero not only breaks through the fourth wall but deconstructs it in many ways. Animal Man is a delightfully bizarre dive into life inside a world where world resets and real-world sales figures can mean life or death to living, breathing characters. However bizarre Morrison‚Äôs Animal Man gets, though, it‚Äôs steered through by Morrison‚Äôs full sincerity and compassion for his characters.If Morrison faced the unenviable task of writing a ‚Äúlast Superman story‚Äù, Miller‚Äôs task of crafting a ‚Äúfinal‚Äù Batman story (ignore that there‚Äôs a pair of pretty terrible sequels) feels nearly impossible. Miller not only succeeds but helped to redefine the character in ways that cast a long shadow even today. The story follows an elderly Bruce Wayne who emerges from retirement for a few nights to don the cape and cowl one last time in a mission to restore order to Gotham city.¬†As we said in the ‚ÄúBest Graphic Novels‚Äù rundown: In all honesty, how could it have been anything else? There are countless blogs devoted to how overrated the comics are, and they‚Äôre all wrong. Nearly every issue in Alan Moore and Dave Gibbons‚Äô 12-issue deconstruction of the superhero genre is perfect and genius on some level ‚Äî particularly The Watchmaker, in which we follow Doctor Manhattan‚Äôs non-linear perception of the world. Every issue, every panel, feels carefully crafted and composed.Watchmen‚Äôs central mystery, who killed The Comedian, is a compelling hook for a story that dives headfirst into Cold War anxieties and meaningful questions about hero worship. There are few stories that can live up to the kind of reputation Watchmen has earned, but it does.

Ranking The Best DC Comic Characters   		Justice League is coming out on Friday and with that, we have another movie list. Today I will be ranking the top DC comic-book characters of all-time. This list is based off of the history and impact on pop culture. I‚Äôm basing this list off because their haven‚Äôt been enough movies in the DCU to make up a top 10 list; like I did with the Marvel list I made 2 weeks ago. With that out of the way, here are the top DC characters of all-time.Honorable Mentions-¬†Two-Face, Ra‚Äôs Al Ghul, Lois Lane, Braniac, Bane, and Green Arrow10 Commissioner Gordon- He‚Äôs not your typical hero but Commissioner James Gordon is the definition of a hero. As the commissioner of Gotham City, he and Batman help clean up the streets of crime. He‚Äôs also the father of Batgirl and is of the Dark Knight‚Äôs most important supporting characters.9 Lex Luthor- As Superman‚Äôs arch enemy, Lex Luthor is one of the most iconic villains in comic-book history. What makes Luthor so scary is that he has the ability to go toe-to-toe with Superman and he doesn‚Äôt have any powers. But it helps when you are the smartest man in the world. Sometimes, it truly is ‚Äúmind over muscle‚Äù.8 Dick Grayson (Robin/Nightwing)- Along with Batman, he and Dick Grayson form one of the most famous dynamic duos in the history of pop culture. Known to many as the original Robin, Grayson has gone on an incredible journey. He‚Äôs gone from a kid full of wonder to the hardened badass hero known as Nightwing.7 Hal Jordan (Green Lantern)- He‚Äôs a galactic space cop and he‚Äôs a one of the original core members of the Justice League. ¬†Originally a fighter pilot, Jordan was chosen by the power ring from the planet Oa to join the Green Lantern Corps. With the ring, Jordan becomes one of the most powerful characters in all of DC Comics.6 Barry Allen (The Flash)- While he‚Äôs not the original Flash (Wally West), Barry Allen is by far the most iconic. After getting hit with a bolt of lightning, Allen gains superhuman speed and even has the ability to time travel. Ezra Miller will be bringing Barry Allen to the big screen for the first time in Justice League.5 Selina Kyle (Catwoman)- Not only is Catwoman the sexiest characters in all of comics, she‚Äôs also one of the best. Selina Kyle is the definition of an anti-hero as she‚Äôs only goal in life is to get rich and look out for her own interests. She‚Äôs also had two incredible portrayals one the big screen; the first being Michelle Pfeiffer and the ladder being Anne Hathaway.4 The Joker- There are countless iconic villains in comic book history, but no one can truly compete with The Joker. I could go on for hours about what makes the Joker so scary but I get down to the nitty. First off, no one knowns who he is (not even Batman) and there‚Äôs no rhyme or reason why he does what he does. He just does horrendous things because he can. He‚Äôs a true psychopath and one of the greatest villains in the history of pop culture.3 Diana Prince (Wonder Woman)- As we move into the DC Trinity, we start with the Warrior. Wonder Woman is the princess of Themyscira and arguably the most iconic female character in all of pop culture. What makes Diana such an incredible character is her strength, both literally and figuratively. Not only does she poses God like strength and extremely skilled in sword fighting, Diana is a very forgiving and loving character. She sees the best in people and that‚Äôs what makes her great.2 Kal-El/Clark Kent (Superman)- As the 1st superhero ever created it‚Äôs safe to say a few of you have heard of Superman. Not only is he one of the most famous superheroes, he‚Äôs arguably the most powerful. I also love the duality of Superman as he comes from two different worlds and two different ideals. You have Kal-El; the all power godlike alien vs Clark Kent; the regular American kid from Kansas. Not only is he trying to be a symbol of hope for the world, but he himself is trying to find his place in it. Deep stuff.1 Bruce Wayne (Batman)- Was there really any doubt here? Not only is Batman the greatest DC character of all-time, he‚Äôs the greatest comic-book character ever created. Not only is he more feared man in the world, he‚Äôs the leader of the Justice League. Oh yea, the man doesn‚Äôt even have any powers! What I love so much about Batman is that he a normal dude who just wants to make the world a better place. Driven by the tragedy of the death of his parents, Batman will never stop and give up on Gotham City. He is vengeance, he is the night, he is the goddamn Batman.Written By: Steven Santoro (SVS_1993)I love sports and movies. Be on the lookout for articles about both. screenrant.comThe 10 Best DC Comic Books Of 2021, According To Reddit2021 marked the start of DC Comics' launch of Infinite Frontier, and fans on Reddit celebrate the various great comic book series that it came with.The last year was another where the comic book industry saw a boost in mainstream commercial and critical success. 2021 was also the year that marked DC Comics' launch of their¬†Infinite Frontier¬†brand-wide initiative to¬†progress beyond¬†2016's¬†Rebirth¬†era.RELATED: 10 Best Daredevil Comics For New Fans To Start WithAside from superhero icons like Batman, Superman, and Wonder Woman, some great creator-driven series have also earned their respective acclaim. Comic book fans on Reddit have shared their thoughts and compiled their lists on what they believe to be the publisher's best work over the last year, ranging from their mainline and alternate canon stories.While his live-action tenure on the then-DC Universe streaming platform was unfortunately cut short, comic book fans commonly regard him as one of DC's best monster characters. Redditor LordCosmagog¬†chimes in saying "For me, the best books of the last 12 months have been Justice League Dark & Swamp Thing," with the¬†Guardian of the Green being one of JLD's prominent members historically.Ram V.'s¬†The Swamp Thing¬†limited series garnered consistently high praise across its 10-issue run in its introduction of the next Guardian of the Green and new compelling, emotional themes that the likes of Alan Moore revitalized the character with. The great reception of the series led DC to greenlight another six issues for another run.The recent trailer for¬†The Batman¬†has stirred even more fan excitement, making now a good time for fans to read Mattson Tomlin's¬†Batman: The Imposter. Tomlin was brought on in 2019 to assist Reeves and Peter Craig in writing the movie, and the premise and quality of the series seem like a clear influence from his time on it.It's perhaps the most grounded the Dark Knight has been in comics, focusing on a gritty, street-level crime-noir story of someone impersonating Batman to ruin his young reputation. Redditor SequentialNation¬†compiled a list including "the various excellent creator-driven books from DC Black Label," with¬†The Imposter¬†among them. Its¬†praise is further testament to DC Black Label publishing some of the best modern Batman comics.While still in the realm of DC Black Label, James Tynion IV's¬†The Nice House on the Lake¬†is an isolated horror series to change the pace. The writer came from a well-received tenure on¬†Detective Comics¬†and recently wrapped up his¬†Batman¬†run, with Tynion¬†emphasizing that his best strengths come the bizarre and frightening.RELATED: 10 Best Comic Books Ever, According To RankerRedditor TerraObus¬†responds to the aforementioned list saying that "Most of my top 10 comics of the year are listed up here," and that "The Nice House On The Lake is the best of the bunch." The series is six issues in with another half-dozen to go, and it's already enthralling readers with visually striking moments of terror and character drama.Another former¬†Batman¬†writer transitioned over to DC Black Label for something refreshing. Tom King's¬†Batman¬†may have had its ups and downs, but his subversive noir "whodunit"-style¬†The Human Target¬†has been a proven hit. Redditor boom-bam¬†praises the series saying "he‚Äôs playing with all the classic noir tropes but having them play out in the superhero world."The story prides itself on influence from the classic, pulpy detective-noir stories of the 20th century while simultaneously, as the same Redditor points out, subverting that genre's tropes "by¬†having it play out in these beautiful splashy neon colors and Smallwood‚Äôs kinda hopeful lovely optimistic drawings."Being DC Comics' best street-level superhero, Batman is a character prime for anthology-style crime-drama adventures as well as the typical long-form story arcs. The announcement of¬†Urban Legends¬†signaled a¬†further emphasis¬†on this storytelling style, bringing together various accomplished creators from the comic book industry to make their mark on the Caped Crusader's celebrated mythos.One of which includes Chip Zdarsky, the current writer of¬†the¬†ongoing and acclaimed¬†Daredevil¬†series for Marvel. Redditor FranklinRichardss¬†agrees with DC's success saying "I mean in a lot of genres and format. DC released awesome comics this year," citing¬†Urban Legends¬†in their list of the year's best works.DC Black Label has also introduced more Wonder Woman into the mix, giving the Princess of Themyscira more of the spotlight she deserves. This series continues the fan-favorite¬†brand of the "color" series alongside the¬†flagship¬†Batman: Black & White.RELATED: 10 Best Teenage Superhero Characters, According To RankerThe previous Redditor gives it particular praise with the other color series saying "I'm not even talking about color series they [have] done for Superman, Batman, and Wonder Woman." Like the other two members of The Trinity, Wonder Woman's¬†Black & Gold¬†series was well-received for gathering various creatives to celebrate the history of an iconic superhero in several anthology stories.The¬†Infinite Frontier¬†relaunch was also a major milestone for Superman. Superman's main comic book series has been the self-titled series and¬†Action Comics, but this year marked a sort of relaunch for¬†Superman¬†with the subtitle¬†Son of Kal-El. Fan-favorite writer Tom Taylor helmed the series as its writer, and it's been a great success so far.Redditor FranklinRichardss also highlights¬†Son of Kal-El¬†for being part of DC's "multiple LGBT+ stories," as it revealed Jonathan Kent coming out as bisexual. Jon Kent getting a turn in the spotlight has been a long time coming since he and Damian Wayne have been favorites¬†in the form of the Super-Sons for some time already.¬†Taylor's series has been praised for its emotional, character-focused writing.The same Redditor also includes¬†Nightwing¬†in DC's corner of mainline successes over the past year, with Dick Grayson seeing a return to form in the current Tom Taylor run. Grayson will always be a widely beloved member of the Bat-family, in part for being the original second-half of the Dynamic Duo, but also being a likable, interesting, and charming character in his own right.Nightwing's current high praises largely go toward its grounded approach by making use of the "soft-reboot" formula that understands the fundamentals of what makes him such a lovable hero. At the same time, it's a great jumping-on point for those who are new or have been away for some time.Also in Wonder Woman's corner of the world, DC Black Label's¬†Wonder Woman Historia: The Amazons¬†series¬†only has had one issue published so far, yet is already turning many fans' heads. Redditor SequentialNation included the comic in their list when referring to the "excellent creator-driven books from DC Black Label."RELATED: 10 DC Heroes That Are Darker Than Their VillainsThe Amazons¬†so far is a sprawling odyssey of a story that packs a thoroughly engrossing plot, gods true to the original folklore, and visually-stunning artwork on every page thanks to writer Kelly Sue DeConnick and artist Phil Jimenez. Issue #1 already sets a high bar, with more creatives set to lend their talents in subsequent issues.The earlier note on "about color series they [have] done for Superman, Batman, and Wonder Woman" also includes¬†Superman: Red & Blue. Like the other color series,¬†Red & Blue¬†has been praised for its tasteful approach in bringing together writers and artists to¬†pay tribute to¬†one of DC Comics' greatest superheroes.The new comic book series makes great use of the anthology-style to tell stories highlighting the history of the character. The stories told throughout its 6-issue run are great for veteran fans looking for a celebration of Superman while also being friendly to newcomers who want to get to know the superhero icon.NEXT: 10 Best Animated Batman Movies, According To RankerGuillermo Kurten is a journalism major at the University of Houston. Originally from Caracas, Venezuela, he now resides in Houston. He is a fan of pretty much anything involving nerd culture. Video games, comics, movies, TV, anime, manga, you name it. He also has experience writing about soccer, specifically, the German team Bayern Munich.

Best DC Comics Of 2018Comic Book HeraldA Comic Book Reading Order Guide For Beginners & FansJune 18, 2018 by Dave 6 Comments DC Comics has maintained their status as comic book retailer and critic‚Äôs favorite son throughout 2018. Now approximately two years since the launch of DC Universe: Rebirth #1, the publisher has been hitting a *majority* of the right notes (though far from all given the damn countless number of comics credits that still bear the dark mark of Eddie Berganza). Likewise, the publisher‚Äôs major 2018 event, DC Metal, was one of the best superhero crossovers of the decade, setting the stage for a compelling Justice League lineup through the end of the year.Recent moves suggest this PR glory boat may come to a fiery end by the time 2018 turns one. DC made the strange decision to raise prices nearly linewide to $3.99, while simultaneously removing digital codes from nearly all comics (‚ÄúWhat we lack in talent, we make up for in ineptitude.‚Äù) Likewise, both DC‚Äôs ‚ÄúNew Age of Heroes‚Äù and ‚ÄúDoomsday Clock‚Äù haven‚Äôt struck much of the desired cultural chord, and the publisher has absolutely *none* of the built-in movie hype that Marvel Comics *should* in theory reap the benefits of.Still, there‚Äôs a lot to find exciting about DC‚Äôs back half, including their ‚ÄúBlack Label‚Äù lineup that will include the likes of Frank Miller and John Romita Jr producing ‚ÄúSuperman: Year One.‚Äù Mix in writer Tom King‚Äôs promised 100 issues on Batman, Brian Michael Bendis‚Äô rebirth on Superman, and the promise of a Lex Luthor/Porky Pig one-shot, and it‚Äôs easy to get wildly excited.Related Reading Orders:BatmanComic Book Herald is reader-supported. When you buy through links on our site, we may earn a qualifying affiliate commission.Comic Book Herald‚Äôs reading orders and guides are also made possible by reader support on Patreon, and generous reader donations.Any size contribution will help keep CBH alive and full of new comics guides and content. Support¬†CBH on Patreon¬†for exclusive rewards, or Donate here!¬†Thank you for reading!Become a Patron!CatwomanPublished bi-weekly, Batman is defined by inconsistency. Late 2017 saw the title seemingly ascending to perfection with a run of ‚ÄúBatman Annual #2‚Äù and the ‚ÄúSuperfriends‚Äù double date story arc in Batman #36 to #37. 2018 has seen writer Tom King and a rotating cast of fantastic artists including Joelle Jones, Clay Mann, and Tony Daniel, come back to earth ‚Äì meaning this is simply *one* of the best DC Comics of the year, not the *absolute* best.Related Reading Orders:DC MetalOn ‚ÄúBest Comics Ever,‚Äù Comic Book Herald‚Äôs all-new podcast, I made DC Metal my first deep dive topic, and concluded it‚Äôs the second best superhero event of the decade (just behind Marvel‚Äôs 2015 Secret Wars). Events and crossovers are *rarely* this engaging, and almost never this cohesive, yet New 52 Batman team Scott Snyder and Greg Capullo (with plenty of help from their friends) deliver a cosmic Justice League epic worthy of the ‚ÄúCrisis‚Äù adjacent status.Related Reading Orders:DeathstrokeQuickly escalated from ‚Äúinteresting‚Äù to ‚Äúmust-read‚Äù status in year one, and shows no signs of slowing during the collective comics Christopher Priest appreciation resurgence.Related Reading Orders:Justice LeagueThe biggest downside to Christopher Priest‚Äôs time writing Justice League is that it only lasted 10 issues before the big linewide shakeup.Related Reading Orders:¬†SupermanThere‚Äôs been so much hype about longtime Marvel writer Brian Michael Bendis‚Äô move to DC‚Äôs Superman, that it‚Äôs easy to overlook what has been one of DC‚Äôs best comics since Rebirth began. Helmed primarily by Peter Tomasi and Patrick Gleason (with plenty of additional creators), Superman taps into the family dynamics of Lois, Clark, and their son Jon better than just about any comic has this decade.Related Reading Orders:SupermanDamian WayneLooking back, it makes perfect sense that Tomasi and Gleason, fresh off excellent work writing Damian Wayne for the New 52‚Äôs Batman and Robin, and actively telling new stories about Superson Jon Kent, would be able to create a delightful early adolescent team-up. Much their fathers, the sons of Batman and Superman play off each other‚Äôs persona‚Äôs for a great balance.Related Reading Orders:DC RebirthThere are higher profile Bat-books, and there are Bat-books with bigger stakes, but few pack the emotional, intimate punch of James Tynion IV‚Äôs time writing Detective Comics.Related Reading Orders:¬†BatmanDespite all the trappings of an overexplored trope trussed up with clever design (what if the Joker was, like, good?), Batman: White Knight delivers a compelling limited series.Related Reading Orders:New GodsDC Rebirth Year TwoEvery issue of Mister Miracle, a twelve issue limited series by Tom King and Mitch Gerads, is a reminder that 1) It‚Äôs the best comic book being published and 2) The New Gods are flipping exploding with boundless potential. Truly, from innovative layouts, to structural mystery, to grin-inducing family humor, Mister Miracle isn‚Äôt just the best DC Comic, it‚Äôs just the best comic.Filed Under: Best of Lists, Featured Tagged With: DC ComicsIf you like Comic Book Herald, and are able to donate, any small contribution will help keep CBH alive and full of new comics guides and content. Donate here! Or, support CBH on Patreon for exclusive rewards! Thank you for reading!Dave is the founder and Editor-in-Chief of Comic Book Herald, and also the Boss of assigning himself fancy titles. He's a long-time comic book fan, and can be seen most evenings in Batman pajama pants. Contact Dave @comicbookherald on Twitter or via email at dave@comicbookherald.com.

Best Comics of 2022 (So Far): DC ComicsAll manner of writing about comic booksBy Zack Quaintance ‚Äî On the heels of one of its strongest 12-month periods in many years, DC Comics has continued that momentum in 2022. In fact, today‚Äôs list of the Best Comics of 2022 ‚Äî DC Comics has that good problem of there being too many excellent series worthy of inclusion. We, however, have done our best to break it down to eight uniformly excellent books that speak to the broader quality of the publisher‚Äôs line. You can find those selections below, and as we noted in the Best Comics of 2022 ‚Äî Marvel Comics list, don‚Äôt forget to check this page every month for an updated ranking.Enjoy!1. Catwoman: Lonely CityWriter/Artist: Cliff ChiangWhy It‚Äôs Cool: There‚Äôs an irony in Catwoman: Lonely City being at the top of our Best Comics of 2022 - DC Comics list, because of this writing in late March, the series hasn‚Äôt released a new issue this year. But the next issue is coming? Catwoman: Lonely City #3 is due out April 19, and series editor Chris Conroy has said it‚Äôs the best issue yet. That‚Äôs saying a lot, a whole lot, given the Catwoman: Lonely City #1 was one of less than five single issue comics that I gave a perfect 10 score to last year. It was, without exaggeration, the best Ôªøsingle issue experience I‚Äôve had with a DC comic in a really long time. A singular and detailed vision from cartoonist Cliff Chiang, the book reads like a 2022 Dark Knight Returns, just focused on Catwoman. She‚Äôs older, piecing together a broken Gotham City where Batman has been dead for years. She‚Äôs mixing it up with new, diverse characters as well as aged Batman rogues who are still kicking around. And it‚Äôs all taking place in a Gotham that Chiang has said is heavily influenced by real world New York City, from its changing culture to its municipal politics. On top of all the visionary artwork and character-driven attention to detail, this series also has charm to spare. It‚Äôs a deeply heartfelt and at times funny book, one that entertains in unique and special ways on every page.Pre-Order The Hardcover: Catwoman - Lonely City HCRead The First Issue Digitally: Catwoman - Lonely City #12. The Nice House on the LakeWriter: James Tynion IVArtist: √Ålvaro Mart√≠nez BuenoMost Recent Trade: Nice House on the Lake, Vol. 1Why It‚Äôs Cool: The Nice House on the Lake #1 was one of the other five comics last year that I gave a perfect 10 out of 10 too. It really is a perfect debut issue, one that is imaginative, chilling, stylish, and as assured as a new comic gets. In the other six issues that have so far come out, Ôªøthe book has progressed and evolved, become perhaps one of the best pieces of pandemic fiction, a perfect horror/sci-fi reflection of how it feels to live through a chaotic world in relative comfort, guilty and powerless to some extent to do anything about what‚Äôs happening.The other quality that lands The Nice House on the Lake at our number two spot is the stunning artwork by √Ålvaro Mart√≠nez Bueno, colored to eerie perfection by Jordie Bellaire. This is a DC comic, published through the Black Label imprint, but there‚Äôs no predictable superhero visuals to this book. The work Bueno is doing here feels imaginative and wholly new, with surprises often coming after any page turn. It feels in the best way like Vertigo Comics at its height, just in terms of competency, smarts, and risk-taking. This book is another must-read.3. Action ComicsWriter: Phillip Kennedy JohnsonPrimary Artists: Daniel Sampere, Miguel Mendonca, and Riccardo FedericiMost Recent Trade: Superman - Action Comics, Vol. 1 - Warworld RisingWhy It‚Äôs Cool: I like this run so much that it inspired me to write a piece called It‚Äôs Time to Talk About Action Comics because it Whips Ass. And it absolutely does. It‚Äôs a story in which Superman gets lost in space with an updated, 2022 version of The Authority. Operating outside the nascent ‚Äî and currently underpowered ‚Äî United Planets‚Äô perview, Superman has decided to take on the most-recent, very powerful Mongul and his warworld. What has ensued is a deep space gladiator epic (a bit like World War Hulk, but also not at all like World War Hulk), where Superman is working to liberate a full planet of oppressed people with his powers dampened. At the same time, members of his splintered team are working in the shadows to foment a revolution. Simply put, these are high-action, giant sci-fi concept, complex comics. They‚Äôre armed with fantastic, grandiose artists, a writer who is nailing every story beat, and a sense of momentum I haven‚Äôt felt from an individual Superman comic in many years. If you‚Äôre looking for an engaging more traditional superhero comic than the first two on this list, this is the one.Other Relevant Trades: Future State - Superman; Superman & The Authority; Superman - The One Who Fell; and Superman - Action Comics, Vol. 1 - Warworld Rising4. Human TargetWriter: Tom KingArtist: Greg SmallwoodMost Recent Trade: Human Target, Vol. 1Why It‚Äôs Cool: I am a sucker for any comic that takes tropes from other genres and affixes them to superhero characters. DC Comics has done this really well in recent years, with stories like DCeased, which is what if zombie apocalypse but with DC characters, as well as with Dark Knights of Steel, which is what if twisty political fantasy epic but with DC characters. Human Target, however, is my favorite of them all, and it‚Äôs what if old Hollywood noir but with DC characters, specifically the characters from the classic run of Justice League International. What makes this comic truly special is the pop-art sequential storytelling being done by Greg Smallwood, which has just been stunning. Combine that with Tom King‚Äôs clear common of punchy, old-time dialogue complete with over-the-top exaggerated hard-boiled characterization, and you get an excellent comic that reads unlike any other book from DC. There‚Äôs some grumbling out there about the relationship this comic has to the source material, but this is essentially an Elseworld story, where taking liberties with the characters is part of the point.5. One Star SquadronWriter: Mark RussellArtist: Steve LieberWhy It‚Äôs Cool: This is another book that sort of fits into what I was writing about above, the type of out-of-continuity superhero comics that use these well-known characters in the service of exploring other types of story. In this case, it‚Äôs superheroes meets Glengarry Glen Ross, and, if I‚Äôm being honest, the superheroes aren‚Äôt all that well-known. No, this is a book about the deepest of deep DC Universe bench characters, who are now working for a new app-based company where users can pay to rent hero‚Äôs time, doing so for everything from temporary security gigs to making appearances at children‚Äôs birthday parties.The real villain of this story is, of course, corporate greed, which turns even people who use extraordinary powers to combat evil into faceless pieces of a machine, susceptible at any time to the machinations of a few suited folks in a boardroom. Armed with writer Mark Russell‚Äôs signature satiric wit and the clever-but-heartfelt cartooning of Steve Lieber, One-Star Squadron rounds out the top five of our best comics of 2022 ‚Äî DC Comics list.Read The First Issue: One-Star Squadron #1 Digital 6. Arkham City: The Order of the WorldWriter: Dan WattersArtist: DaniWhy It‚Äôs Cool: Like the majority of the in-continuity Batman comics right now, Arkham City - The Order of the World depicts an interesting corner of Gotham City that we don‚Äôt get to often see in the main title. It‚Äôs a story that features Azrael, some familiar old villains, and one absolutely chilling new villain that I hope we get to see again, sooner rather than later. This is perhaps the Batman comic right now that has the most experimental concepts, armed as it is as well with a chic almost-abstract indie comics aesthetic. Writer Dan Watters and artist Dani are a hell of a team ‚Äî as see in the hit indie comic series, Coffin Bound ‚Äî and it‚Äôs been a real treat to see them taking their talents to Gotham. This is a six-issue miniseries that recently concluded, with a trade collection presumably on the way at some point later this year.Read The First Issue: Arkham City - The Order of the World #1 Digital7. The Swamp ThingWriter: Ram V.Primary Artist: Mike PerkinsMost Recent Trade: The Swamp Thing, Vol. 1 ‚Äî BecomingWhy It‚Äôs Cool: Excuse this absolutely awful bit of punning, but this new run of The Swamp Thing has made for fertile ground for some of the best superhero comics at DC. Very sorry about that, but it‚Äôs true. This is an updated take on the character, one that uses Mike Perkins gritty cartooning and Ram V‚Äôs knack for poetic scripting to give this series a poignant sensibility that feels apart from anything else coming from DC Comics. In that way, it‚Äôs a book I‚Äôd recommend to readers who are new to the character but have enjoyed Ram V‚Äôs work around mythology and colonialism in his indie breakout titles ‚Äî These Savage Shores and The Many Deaths of Laila Star, chief among them ‚Äî as well as to readers who enjoy a good story about Swamp Thing.Read The First Issue: The Swamp Thing #1 DigitalRead our full review of the first trade!8. Batman/Superman ‚Äî World‚Äôs FinestWriter: Mark WaidArtist: Dan MoraWhy It‚Äôs Cool: The art on this book is absolutely beautiful, looking as bright and iconic as these characters can. Dan Mora, with colors by Tamra Bonvillain, is just doing absolutely stunning work. Making things even better, is that Mark Waid (Kingdom Come) is back at DC Comics, doing his first proper run on a title in I don‚Äôt know how long, and it feels like he‚Äôs been saving this story for years. It‚Äôs fast and clever and it seems determined to span some of the most fun corners of the DC Universe, from obscure Superman villians to steady cameo appearances by the Doom Patrol. This is perhaps the best book right now for fans of traditional DC superhero comics, and it‚Äôs just getting started.Read The First Issue: Batman/Superman ‚Äî World‚Äôs Finest #1 DigitalRead our review of the first issue!9. Monkey PrinceWriter: Gene Luen Yang Ê•äË¨πÂÄ´Artist: Bernard Chang Âºµ‰ºØÁ¥çWhy It‚Äôs Cool: Writer Gene Luen Yang, teamed here with artist Bernard Chang, is doing perhaps his most personal work yet for DC Comics, having created a new superhero for the publisher that springs from the same mythology that informed/appeared in Yang‚Äôs breakout graphic novel, American Born Chinese, one of the true must-read comics of the past 20 years. This series is about a teen superhero coming to terms with a power set and a power source unlike anything we‚Äôve really seen in Big 2 superhero comics. On top of that, Yang and Chang also infuse the entire story with a sense of fun and a hilarious, attitude-heavy sense of humor. There‚Äôs so much that makes this a fun, colorful read, a different kind of superhero comic that‚Äôs perfect for readers of all ages. Read The First Issue: Monkey Prince #1 DigitalRead our review of the first issue!10. The JokerWriter: James Tynion IVPrimary Artist: Guillem MarchMost Recent Trade: The Joker, Vol. 1 HardcoverWhy It‚Äôs Cool: A series about The Joker is not necessarily something I‚Äôd be into, and yet this still one of my favorite Batman-adjacent comics, landing it a spot on my Best Comics of 2022 DC Comics list. While The Joker obviously takes the title and the focus of the book‚Äôs marketing, this series is really about Commissioner Jim Gordon, who has quite a bit of history with the titular villain. This series grew directly from the biggest event to happen in the Batman comics in some time, wherein someone gassed the villains at Arkham Asylum, and the crime was blamed on The Joker. This book sees Jim Gordon on a globetrotting hunt for The Joker, financed by a shady group of wealthy Gothamies who are fed up with The Joker‚Äôs chaos and murder. The result is a complex and interesting character-driven series that makes the most of Batman continuity, past and present.Read The First Issue: The Joker #1 DigitalHonorable Mentions: Batman Killing Time, Batman ‚Äî The Knight, Dark Knights of Steel, DC Vs. Vampires, Detective Comics, Nightwing, Robin, Task Force Z, and Wonder Woman.This section is dedicated to recent DC Comics trade collections and graphic novels newly available in 2022. I highly recommend this entire list, almost all of which can be picked up by new or lapsed readers and enjoyed on its own merits. Each entry below goes back to the start of its given run, although some are ongoing and many are self-contained and a few others are forthcoming. At any rate, so far these are the best DC Comics trade collections of 2022 (so far)‚Ä¶enjoy!Absolute Fourth World by Jack Kirby, Vol. 2: PhysicalAbsolute Multiversity: PhysicalAll-Star Superman: The Deluxe Edition: PhysicalBatman: The Imposter: Physical / DigitalThe Flintstones: Deluxe Edition: PhysicalGotham Central Omnibus: PhysicalThe Nice House on the Lake, Vol. 1: Physical / DigitalRepresent!: Physical / DigitalSupergirl: Woman of Tomorrow: PhysicalSuperman ‚Äò78: PhysicalSuperman and the Authority: Physical / DigitalSuperman Red and Blue: Collected: Physical / DigitalCheck out the Best Comics of 2022 (So Far): Marvel Comics list!Read more great graphic novel and comics reviews!Zack Quaintance is a tech reporter by day and freelance writer by night/weekend. Top 10 Marvel Comics of 2019

                                SUPER HERO JUNKY                            
The Super Hero Addicts Rehab Center2019 is coming to a close and this is our list for the best Marvel Comics of 2019. Marvel had an amazing year. Lots of great stories came in 2019. From cosmic battles to amazing character deconstruction, from heartfelt comedy to serious issues, Marvel splendidly showcased some of the most amazing stories of the year.So before diving right into the list.Note:Fantastic Four: Dan Slott(W),
Meet The Skrulls: Robbie Thompson(W)
Guardians of the Galaxy: Donny Cates(W)
Friendly Neighborhood Spider-Man: Tom Taylor(W)
Killmonger: Bryan Hill(W)Without further ado:Writer(s): Donny CatesArtist(s): Tradd MooreLast Issue: #5What‚Äôs not to love about this book. Trad Moores‚Äôs artwork is criticized for this book, but for me Moore‚Äôs art was fresh. It wasn‚Äôt everyone‚Äôs cup of tea.¬† The story was brilliant as well. Silver Surfer is sucked into a black hole where he finds a nemesis older than time itself.Writer(s): Ed BrissonArtist(s): Mike HendersonLast Issue: #12This is the Death of Wolverine done right. Old Man Logan is dying and he got one last task to do. Kill Mysterio. He wants to prevent what happened on his Earth. Brisson really knows this character. Mysterio‚Äôs and Hawkeye‚Äôs characterization are well done. With rough and tuff art by Henderson, what more can you want.Writer(s): Gerry Duggan/ Jim Zub/ Roy ThomasArtist(s): Ron Garney/ Patch Zircher/ Alan DavisCurrent Issue: #112019 was a huge year for Conan. From his introduction into the Marvel Universe to fighting alongside Marvel heroes. This book represents all the Conan comics of 2019. We choose this book for the list because for us this is the best Conan comic right now. The first five issues by Duggan was just grand. This book saw lots of shifts from writers but even that can‚Äôt detract from this amazing story. Currently in the hands of the amazing Roy ThomasWriter(s): Chip ZdarskyArtist(s): Carlos Magno &Butch GuiceCurrent Issue: #11Anyone who is a fan of Marvel comics knows too well that Donny Cates and Chip Zdarsky are THE best writers Marvel has to offer in 2019. This book is about Marvel‚Äôs very first team. Captain America, Namor, Human Torch and Winter Soldier. But now Namor declared war against the surface world. Every issue is a breathtaking ride and rightfully deserves a spot on any top 10 list.Writer(s): Mark WaidArtist(s): Jesus Saiz/ Javier PinaLast Issue: #20Clearly one of the underrated Marvel comics in 2019. Started with Steven Strange finding the cure of magic in space adventure then squaring off with Dormammu with newfound allies. This series is just pure fun to read. Then Waid is joined by Barry Kitson(W) and Scott Koblish(A) to tell the story of Herald Supreme. The story at times feels a little too rushed but it‚Äôs still definitely worth the read.Writer(s): El EwingArtist(s): Joe BennettCurrent Issue: #27This book was our #1 pick for Best Marvel Comic of 2018. The only reason it is not our #1 this year because 1-4 are just too good. It started as a horror book, then Hulk was in hell, fought Shadowbase and now cosmic. This book is just perfect. The art of Joe Bennett is justly fitting for this book.Writer(s): Christos GageArtist(s): Mike HawthroneLast Issue: #12When this book started I wasn‚Äôt sure where it was going or if it was even necessary. Back in 2012, Slott had already told a perfect ending, but as the story untold, man was I wrong. This book deals with Otto being a hero and a second chance at life. The whole characterization and deconstruction of a character and the relation with a new side of the character is pure joy.Writer(s): Jonathan HickmanArtist(s): Pepe Larraz(HoX)/ R B Silva(PoX)Current/Last Issue: #6 issue eachThese 2 comics right here literally revolutionized the X-Men. Charles Xavier is done with his dream of mutant equality. He is shown why he will always fail. Now its time to take action into his own hands. We can‚Äôt emphasize how amazing these books are. Every issue is unpredictable. Readers will never know what‚Äôs going to hit them in the next issue. The spin off of these books is Dawn of X which is equally amazing. A little slow but still worth reading.Writer(s): Donny CatesArtist(s): Ryan StegmanCurrent/Last Issue: #20(Venom) / #5(Absolute Carnage)I personally am not a Venom fan. But what Donny Cates did with Venom is spectacular. He created a whole mythos around the symbiote species. This comic is a well-crafted tale of both symbiote and Eddie Brock. While talking about Absolute Carnage, this event is undoubtedly the BEST Marvel event of 2019.Writer(s): Chip ZdarskyArtist(s):¬†Marco Checchetto/ Lalit Kumar SharmaCurrent Issue: #14We have Hulk going cosmic, Venom got a Symbiote God and X-Men have been revolutionized while Daredevil is suffering from mental issues. This is the deconstruction of the character done perfectly. Art varies from issue to issue but it least affects the story which is inexpressibly beautiful. So if you want to read only one comic this year, then this is the comic.If your favorite comics of 2019 aren‚Äôt on the list then comment it down below and tell us why you loved it!!Great list Vince, Marvel really had some great books this year. I personally feel that they beat DC this year. YOTV really hasn‚Äôt done much in my opinion.Thanks, Nick. Loved that you enjoyed the list!!Great list with some truly accurate reviews- daredevil is by far the best, nothing I ever like ever finished top so thanks for that üòä look forward to 2020!
